qas.question: What rule gives minority leader right to offer motion to recommit with instructions?
Who may place legislation on a corrections calendar?
Minority leader may appoint individuals to what government roles?

plausible_answers.text: appointing individuals to certain federal entities

qas.question: What other institutional duties does the Inspector General have?

plausible_answers.text: the right to offer a motion to recommit with instructions

qas.question: What does Rule XII, clause 6 grant the Inspector General?

plausible_answers.text: the Speaker, majority leader, and minority leader

qas.question: Who are able to appoint individuals to the House according to Rule II, clause 6?
Who does the Inspector General have to consult with according to Rule XV, clause 6?

plausible_answers.text: may place legislation on the Corrections Calendar

qas.question: What can the Inspector General do after consulting with the minority leader?

context: From an institutional perspective, the rules of the House assign a number of specific responsibilities to the minority leader. For example, <a0_0>Rule XII, clause 6<a0_0/>, grant the minority leader (or his designee) <b4_0>the right to offer a motion to recommit with instructions<b4_0/>; Rule II, clause 6, states the Inspector General shall be appointed by joint recommendation of <b5_0>the Speaker, majority leader, and minority leader<b5_0/>; and Rule XV, clause 6, provides that the Speaker, after consultation with <b6_0>the <a1_0>minority leader<b6_0/><a1_0/>, <b7_0>may place legislation on the Corrections Calendar<b7_0/>. The minority leader also has other institutional duties, such as <b3_0>appointing individuals to <a2_0>certain federal entities<b3_0/>.
